hints_html: How can you use the height function \(h(t)\) to know the change of the height between day \(4\) and day \(5\).
hints_latex:
How can you use the height function $h(t)$ to know the change of the
height between day $4$ and day $5$.
hints_raw: How can you use the height function <math> h(t)\ </math> to know the change of the height between day <math>\ 4</math> and day <math>\ 5</math>.
question: 8 (c)
sols_html:
The change of height between day \(4\) and \(5\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \ h(5)-h(4) &= \frac{e^{\frac52}-1}{e^{\frac12}-1} - \frac{e^{\frac42}-1}{e^{\frac12}-1}\\ &= \frac{e^{2.5}-e^2}{e^{\frac12}-1} = e^2\frac{e^{\frac12} - 1}{e^{\frac12} - 1} = e^2\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The change of height between day <math>\ 4</math> and <math>\ 5</math> is

<math>\begin{align}
\ h(5)-h(4) &= \frac{e^{\frac52}-1}{e^{\frac12}-1} - \frac{e^{\frac42}-1}{e^{\frac12}-1}\\
 &= \frac{e^{2.5}-e^2}{e^{\frac12}-1} = e^2\frac{e^{\frac12} - 1}{e^{\frac12} - 1} = e^2
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
The growth rate of a plant during the first week after germination is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g(t) = ae^{t/2} \text{ mm/day},\end{aligned}\]

where the time t is measured in days, and a is a constant.

How much did the plant grow on the fifth day (i.e. between t = 4 and t = 5)? (If you don’t know the constant a, use a = 1.)
statement_raw:
The growth rate of a plant during the first week after germination is given by

:<math>\displaystyle g(t) = ae^{t/2} \text{ mm/day}, </math>

where the time ''t'' is measured in days, and ''a'' is a constant.

How much did the plant grow on the fifth day (i.e. between ''t = 4'' and ''t = 5'')? (If you don't know the constant ''a'', use ''a = 1''.)
